docs.lead_paragraph: The malaise that grips the New York theater did not go away in 1983, but who would deny that the year ended with a jolly bang? The explosion was Michael Frayn's ''Noises Off,'' an ingenious English farce that is not only giving Broadway some welcome hilarity, but is also providing a much needed reminder of the theater's ability to endure in the midst of disaster. ''Noises Off'' is a play about theater professionals who somehow make the show go on even when the show is terrible and the scenery is all but falling down. Mr. Frayn didn't write his farce as a parable about the New York theater, 1983, but it could most hearteningly serve as one. During the past dozen months, our theater artists struggled, often with success, to reaffirm their most durable traditions in the face of mounting imaginative and economic calamities.
